com.stormpath.shiro.authz

Class CustomDataPermissionsEditor

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.shiro.authz.CustomDataPermissionsEditor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PermissionsEditor

    public class CustomDataPermissionsEditor
extends Object
implements PermissionsEditor
    A CustomDataPermissionsEditor can read or modify a collection of Shiro permission Strings stored in a CustomData resource. This is used to support a common convention for Shiro+Stormpath applications: you can assign Shiro permissions to an Account or a Group by storing those permissions in the respective account or group's CustomData map.

    Usage

    You may use this component to 'wrap' a CustomData instance, and it will read or modify the CustomData's permissions Set as necessary. This implementation assumes a single CustomData field that contains a Set of Strings.

    For example: 

         CustomData data = account.getCustomData();
     new CustomDataPermissionsEditor(customData)
         .append("user:1234:edit")
         .append("document:*")
         .remove("printer:*:print");
     data.save();
    Invoking this code would remove the first two permissions and remove the 3rd.

    Note however that manipulating the permissions Set only makes changes locally. You must call customData.save() (or account.save() or group.save()) to persist the the changes back to Stormpath.

    Field Name

    This implementation assumes a CustomData field named apacheShiroPermissions to store the Set of shiro permissions, implying the following CustomData JSON structure: 
     {
     ... any other of your own custom data properties ...,

     "apacheShiroPermissions": [
         "perm1",
         "perm2",
         ...,
         "permN"
     ]
 }
    You can set the fieldName property if you would like to change this name to something else. For example, if you changed the name to myApplicationPermissions, you would see the resulting CustomData JSON structure: 
     {
     ... any other of your own custom data properties ...,

     "myApplicationPermissions": [
         "perm1",
         "perm2",
         ...,
         "permN"j
     ]
 }
    Since:
    0.5

    • Method Detail

      • getFieldName

        public String getFieldName()
        Returns the name of the CustomData field used to store the Set&lt;String&gt; of permissions. The default name is apacheShiroPermissions, implying a CustomData JSON representation as follows: 
         {
     ... any other of your own custom data properties ...,

     "apacheShiroPermissions": [
         "perm1",
         "perm2",
         ...,
         "permN"j
     ]
 }
        You can change the name by calling setFieldName(String).
        Returns:
        the name of the CustomData field used to store the Set&lt;String&gt; of permissions.

      • setFieldName

        public CustomDataPermissionsEditor setFieldName(String fieldName)
        Sets the name of the CustomData field used to store the Set&lt;String&gt; of permissions. The default name is apacheShiroPermissions, implying a CustomData JSON representation as follows: 
         {
     ... any other of your own custom data properties ...,

     "apacheShiroPermissions": [
         "perm1",
         "perm2",
         ...,
         "permN"j
     ]
 }
        If you changed this name to be myApplicationPermissions for example, the CustomData representation would look something like this instead: 
         {
     ... any other of your own custom data properties ...,

     "myApplicationPermissions": [
         "perm1",
         "perm2",
         ...,
         "permN"j
     ]
 }

        Usage Warning

        If you change this value, you will also need to adjust your ApplicationRealm instance's configuration to reflect this name so it can continue to function - the realm reads the same CustomData field, so they must be identical to ensure both read and write scenarios access the same field.

        For example, if using shiro.ini: 

         stormpathRealm.groupPermissionResolver.customDataFieldName = myApplicationPermissions
 stormpathRealm.accountPermissionResolver.customDataFieldName = myApplicationPermissions
        Parameters:
        fieldName - the name of the CustomData field used to store the Set&lt;String&gt; of permissions.
        Returns:
        this object for method chaining.

      • getPermissionStrings

        public Set<String> getPermissionStrings()
        Description copied from interface: PermissionsEditor
        Returns a read-only (immutable) view of the stored permission strings. An immutable empty set will be returned if there are not any currently stored.
        Specified by:
        getPermissionStrings in interface PermissionsEditor
        Returns:
        an immutable view of the stored permission strings.
